Fundus photography shows a series of parallel horizontal striations (encapsulated within the red box, identified with red arrows). On OCT, wrinkling of the inner retina is seen without changes in the choroid, indicating these are retinal folds (yellow arrows).

A dilated fundus examination is performed with OCT 5-line raster images with vertically-oriented lines as shown above. What is the main abnormality seen on the OCT?

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
![](/content/media/neuro-ophthalmology-12-9.webp)

Fundus auto-fluorescence provided additional confirmation of retinal folds. Linear striations with increased signal intensity are visualized as shown above (red arrows). What are potential causes of retinal folds?

answers.explanation:
In most cases, the etiology is unclear, however compressive lesions, hypotony, hyperopia and scleral inflammation are known to cause retinal folds. When determining the cause of retinal folds, history and further investigations can aid in determining etiology. The patient’s past medical history is significant for multiple myeloma (MM). Plasmacytoma (plasma cell tumour) may occur in end-stage MM patients and is the most likely cause for the retinal folds seen in this patient (Knapp 1987).

References

Knapp AJ, Gartner S, Henkind P. Multiple myeloma and its ocular manifestations. Surv Ophthalmol. 1987;31(5):343-51

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: Given the examination and OCT findings, where is the compressive lesion causing the optic neuropathy?

answers.explanation:
The inner retinal folds are due to compression of the globe by a retrobulbar mass. A T2-weighted MRI orbits was performed, showing large orbital plasmacytomas (red arrows) involving the medial rectus muscle bilaterally. Right optic nerve compression can be seen on the transverse image (red circle).

![](/content/media/neuro-ophthalmology-12-10.webp)

![](/content/media/neuro-ophthalmology-12-11.webp)

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text: What is the most common ocular complications associated with multiple myeloma?

answers.explanation: Complications of multiple myeloma result from the accumulation of immunoglobulin light chains in organ systems (ex. kidney, bone, gastro-intestinal tract, central/peripheral nervous system...). Immunoglobulins and plasma cells can accumulate in the many ocular structures including the ciliary body, retina, cranial nerves, surrounding musculature and soft tissue. Neuro-ophthalmic manifestations are generally most common – cranial nerve 6 palsy is the most common neuro-ophthalmic complication observed in multiple myeloma, likely due to the long course of the nerve (Fung 2005). Regarding the patient in the case presented, plasmacytomas are present in the medial rectus behind the globe and are compressing the optic nerve. This resulted in right RAPD and reduced visual acuity, as well as the retinal folds seen on OCT/fundus photography. Diplopia may arise with further retro-orbital infiltration due to plasmacytomas. This patient is at risk for developing a retinal detachment, as the retinal folds indicate extrinsic force on the retina.
